rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (upbeat techno music)}
{\rtf1 For this lab, we're basically}
{\rtf1 going to be analyzing logon events,}
{\rtf1 whether they're successful\par or failed logons}
{\rtf1 because one of the most common things}
{\rtf1 for adversaries or malware to do}
{\rtf1 is to steal credentials and reuse,}
{\rtf1 and then repeat and re-rinse.}
{\rtf1 Rather than constantly\par exploiting, which is unpredictable}
{\rtf1 and can crash things, why\par not just steal credentials}
{\rtf1 and then make all the events\par you're doing look normal?}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to be doing is}
{\rtf1 just analyzing the logon events,}
{\rtf1 showing some different\par ways we can look at these.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to look\par at what are the two users}
{\rtf1 with the highest number of failed logons,}
{\rtf1 are these malicious or just errors,}
{\rtf1 because let's face it,\par when you start looking}
{\rtf1 at failed logons in your log net,}
{\rtf1 a lot of times what you're going to find}
{\rtf1 is mis-configured devices.}
{\rtf1 We want to clean those up.}
{\rtf1 What systems or systems are\par these failed logons related?}
{\rtf1 We're going to look for\par pass-the-hash events,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to look for a\par high number of successful logons.}
{\rtf1 To me, I am very much concerned about that}
{\rtf1 because Ransomware or other\par attacks steal credentials,}
{\rtf1 and then they log in\par everywhere to look at things.}
{\rtf1 So I'm just as concerned about\par too many successful logons.}
{\rtf1 Are these malicious in nature?}
{\rtf1 What evidence do we have?}
{\rtf1 And then we're going to look at a}
{\rtf1 vulnerability-scanned\par user account being used}
{\rtf1 outside of what it's intended to,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to find where from}
{\rtf1 and what computer it's\par being used to access.}
{\rtf1 So let's go ahead and start this.}
{\rtf1 For this lab we are using the\par lab three two login dashboard.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to go ahead and load that up.}
{\rtf1 I'm sorry, 3.3 login dashboard.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 So we can see we've got failed logons.}
{\rtf1 We see a spike here in this middle one.}
{\rtf1 We see a logon map that's getting ready}
{\rtf1 to load here in the top right.}
{\rtf1 Sometimes you have to click\par into it for it to show up.}
{\rtf1 We've got successful\par logons, which we have a lot}
{\rtf1 from, looks like J. Henderson.}
{\rtf1 That's me.}
{\rtf1 (Jay laughs)}
{\rtf1 We see successful logons over time.}
{\rtf1 Again, it shows J. Henderson with a ton,}
{\rtf1 and then just a plot to\par show what things look like.}
{\rtf1 So let's start diving into this.}
{\rtf1 First thing we want to do is\par look at the failed logons.}
{\rtf1 Which ones have the\par two most failed logons?}
{\rtf1 This is pretty easy to\par answer cause it's right here,}
{\rtf1 L. Chancello and administrator.}
{\rtf1 There's 116 for L.\par Chancello on file server01}
{\rtf1 and 50 for administrator on file server01.}
{\rtf1 If we look at the other visualization}
{\rtf1 we see this started and\par then immediately spiked}
{\rtf1 over the span of a couple minutes.}
{\rtf1 We see a lot for L. Chancello,}
{\rtf1 and we see a decent amount\par for administrator as well,}
{\rtf1 in the same time period.}
{\rtf1 All right, since we have file server01}
{\rtf1 and a ton of these, that\par already looks suspicious.}
{\rtf1 Why are there so many attempts\par to log on to the file server,}
{\rtf1 and again also with the\par administrator account?}
{\rtf1 So, here's what we're going to do.}
{\rtf1 We're going to go ahead and start}
{\rtf1 by searching in on L. Chancello.}
{\rtf1 We'll zoom in on him for file server one.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to click here.}
{\rtf1 That way it does both of these.}
{\rtf1 Here we go.}
{\rtf1 And we want to start\par looking at these events.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to scroll down.}
{\rtf1 We see this is for a logon type three,}
{\rtf1 which is a network logon.}
{\rtf1 We see the target domain,\par and we want to look}
{\rtf1 at the failed logons, which are 4625s.}
{\rtf1 Make spam one of these.}
{\rtf1 And you'll notice we have the client IP,}
{\rtf1 and we know that it was\par against file system01.}
{\rtf1 And notice right here,\par random workstation name}
{\rtf1 coming from 1921681.51.}
{\rtf1 Again, this is one of\par those things where malware}
{\rtf1 constantly, for some reason,\par will randomize things.}
{\rtf1 It's evasion technique,\par but it's also a tell.}
{\rtf1 And if I were to look\par at the next log here,}
{\rtf1 we'd find that it has a\par different random workstation.}
{\rtf1 Each logon attempt has a\par different random workstation name.}
{\rtf1 Very suspicious.}
{\rtf1 This is common for things\par like brute-force attacks.}
{\rtf1 So all right, so we see that going on.}
{\rtf1 It's also NTLM logons.}
{\rtf1 Let's flip this over and\par look for administrator.}
{\rtf1 I'm just going to edit this in place}
{\rtf1 and see if it looks the same way.}
{\rtf1 Change that to administrator, save,}
{\rtf1 and again I'm going to scroll down}
{\rtf1 and look at some of these logs.}
{\rtf1 We see again, 4625.}
{\rtf1 Scroll down.}
{\rtf1 Administrator, failed\par password, random workstation,}
{\rtf1 same source address, so it looks like}
{\rtf1 some type of attack tool\par is trying to log in,}
{\rtf1 probably guessing, and it's generating}
{\rtf1 a bunch of these failed logon attempts.}
{\rtf1 So all right, so 1921681.51,\par mighty suspicious.}
{\rtf1 Looks like it's brute-forcing\par against file system01}
{\rtf1 using L. Chancello and administrator.}
{\rtf1 We saw lots of failed logons\par from those two failed accounts}
{\rtf1 so those two in particular,\par for some reason,}
{\rtf1 are being targeted.}
{\rtf1 Next we can try to find pass-the-hash.}
{\rtf1 For that, we're looking for logon events.}
{\rtf1 In this case, I've tagged certain events}
{\rtf1 like 4624, as logon events.}
{\rtf1 For this, we're looking for logons}
{\rtf1 that don't pertain to the\par domain of this organization,}
{\rtf1 which in this case is Sec 555.}
{\rtf1 Let me clear out these filters.}
{\rtf1 And I'm going to look for logon events}
{\rtf1 related to not the domain.}
{\rtf1 We scroll down.}
{\rtf1 We see administrator being\par used on IT01 and IT02.}
{\rtf1 Let's go down here.}
{\rtf1 So we see it's used on\par two different machines.}
{\rtf1 Let's go ahead and look at these logs.}
{\rtf1 Let's start with IT01.}
{\rtf1 Let's start here, IT01.}
{\rtf1 Zoom in.}
{\rtf1 We're going to look at these logs in here.}
{\rtf1 Let me start at the top.}
{\rtf1 We see administrator.}
{\rtf1 Expand the log, and\par random workstation name.}
{\rtf1 So it looks like here it was successful,}
{\rtf1 so 4624, so successful.}
{\rtf1 It's over the network.}
{\rtf1 It's using the local\par administrator account.}
{\rtf1 Again, we can't see what the password is,}
{\rtf1 but the administrator account from one box}
{\rtf1 really shouldn't be logging in}
{\rtf1 to the administrator\par account of another box.}
{\rtf1 Let's also take note.}
{\rtf1 It's still from 1.51.}
{\rtf1 All right, what about IT02?}
{\rtf1 I could change this, go back.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to be lazy.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to remove this.}
{\rtf1 And now I'm going to click on IT02.}
{\rtf1 Oh, cancel.}
{\rtf1 IT02, zoom in.}
{\rtf1 And again, we're going to see\par the administrator account,}
{\rtf1 what was it used for.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 There's the administrator.}
{\rtf1 Expand, and we see successful logon,}
{\rtf1 random workstation name, again from}
{\rtf1 the suspicious host 1.51 using}
{\rtf1 the local administrator account.}
{\rtf1 So it looks like pass-the-hash\par was used successfully}
{\rtf1 on IT01 and IT02 from the 1.51 system.}
{\rtf1 Now, if you were paying attention,}
{\rtf1 if you were monitoring the timestamps,}
{\rtf1 if you were doing a\par full-fledged investigation,}
{\rtf1 and you were to try to\par piece these all together,}
{\rtf1 it's weird because you see that}
{\rtf1 the brute-force attack occurred\par after this pass-the-hash.}
{\rtf1 So we see pass-the-hash,\par it was successful.}
{\rtf1 And then later we see a brute-force.}
{\rtf1 Not only do we see the brute-force,}
{\rtf1 but it's targeted cause you remember,}
{\rtf1 it was going after\par administrator and L. Chancello.}
{\rtf1 So what's going on?}
{\rtf1 So theoretically, kind of what might go}
{\rtf1 through your head is, well\par maybe pass-the-hash did work,}
{\rtf1 but the box they pivoted\par to still didn't have}
{\rtf1 credentials or access to the files}
{\rtf1 or whatever they wanted,\par so they needed more access.}
{\rtf1 So then instead of constantly\par doing pass-the-hash}
{\rtf1 cause maybe it didn't work later,}
{\rtf1 they started doing a brute-force.}
{\rtf1 Different things they can go on,}
{\rtf1 but the timeline analysis would help}
{\rtf1 come up with these theories.}
{\rtf1 Let's clear out our\par filters and let's zoom in}
{\rtf1 and see what 1921681.51 is doing.}
{\rtf1 You could either reload the dashboard}
{\rtf1 or remove the filters and\par just change the search.}
{\rtf1 Either's fine.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to zoom in on 1921681.51.}
{\rtf1 Give that a second.}
{\rtf1 And I want to make sure I'm dealing with}
{\rtf1 just the logon events, so\par we'll add this in here.}
{\rtf1 Now wait.}
{\rtf1 Oh, and here we're just finding}
{\rtf1 the host's name for right now.}
{\rtf1 So we see 1.51 and it's\par related to the host of IT03.}
{\rtf1 We can tell that because\par of the column name,}
{\rtf1 host and the host name because logs}
{\rtf1 are being collected from that box as well.}
{\rtf1 So from this information\par alone, I would assume}
{\rtf1 IT03 somehow got compromised, and then}
{\rtf1 that's where the source of these}
{\rtf1 malicious logons are going out.}
{\rtf1 So, all right, what about the abnormal}
{\rtf1 volume of successful logons?}
{\rtf1 Let me put this back to logons.}
{\rtf1 And if you look at the high\par number of successful logons}
{\rtf1 are from J. Henderson and F. Raynor,}
{\rtf1 with J. Henderson logging in\par successfully to multiple boxes}
{\rtf1 and really F. Raynor also\par logging into multiple boxes.}
{\rtf1 What's going on here?}
{\rtf1 First thing we could do is pivot in on me}
{\rtf1 and see what's going on.}
{\rtf1 So we'll say J. Henderson.}
{\rtf1 We can pull me out of,}
{\rtf1 in this case we're going to\par hone in on my user account.}
{\rtf1 And then what we want to do is figure out}
{\rtf1 is this normal or not normal.}
{\rtf1 One of the things we could do here}
{\rtf1 is zoom in on one of these boxes.}
{\rtf1 One of the logic I like to do here}
{\rtf1 is if I'm trying to figure out\par what's being done on the box,}
{\rtf1 I tend to want to do the one that has}
{\rtf1 the least amount of logs because\par it's less data to look at.}
{\rtf1 It's kind of doing that\par needle in a haystack.}
{\rtf1 So I'm looking at J. Henderson and DHSP01.}
{\rtf1 And we look down, and there's\par multiple network logons.}
{\rtf1 All right, so multiple network logons.}
{\rtf1 If we look into these we\par see that they're type three}
{\rtf1 so network, and they're Cerberus.}
{\rtf1 So we're not seeing the NTLM.}
{\rtf1 We're not seeing pass-the-hash.}
{\rtf1 It's just a logon over\par Cerberus from my user account.}
{\rtf1 What we might want to do\par now is that's the logon,}
{\rtf1 we might have to back\par out of the logon events}
{\rtf1 and just see what's related\par between this user and that box.}
{\rtf1 So I might say anywhere J.\par Henderson's in the message}
{\rtf1 and DHSP01's in the message,\par and see what we get.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to remove these filters,}
{\rtf1 and I'm even going to remove the logons}
{\rtf1 cause now I want to see\par more than just logons.}
{\rtf1 So this is kind of an\par investigation process.}
{\rtf1 I'll hit search.}
{\rtf1 Notice the dashboard doesn't work}
{\rtf1 cause I'm not pulling back\par logon events right now.}
{\rtf1 And I see down here, multiple events.}
{\rtf1 I see 4624, that was a logon.}
{\rtf1 I see 4648.}
{\rtf1 You could expand those, but that's dealing}
{\rtf1 with a vulnerability scanner.}
{\rtf1 Let me make sure this switched correctly.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 I was being impatient.}
{\rtf1 So we see 800.}
{\rtf1 800 is a PowerShell log.}
{\rtf1 If we expand that, we see\par Invoke-Command, computer,}
{\rtf1 all computers, and we can\par see what was being invoked.}
{\rtf1 And in here you see I'm restarting NXLog.}
{\rtf1 So PowerShell login's enabled.}
{\rtf1 We'll cover that more in book four.}
{\rtf1 But what's going on is\par just me in the background,}
{\rtf1 making sure that the log agents are}
{\rtf1 all working on all systems\par and collecting logs.}
{\rtf1 It's generating logon events because}
{\rtf1 I'm remotely connecting to all the boxes.}
{\rtf1 This is not malicious.}
{\rtf1 You can literally, with PowerShell logs,}
{\rtf1 put back together everything I'm doing.}
{\rtf1 It's not malicious.}
{\rtf1 It's just me doing\par sysadmin type functions.}
{\rtf1 So J. Henderson, of course\par I'm a good guy, right?}
{\rtf1 You guys love me, I hope.}
{\rtf1 (laughs loudly)}
{\rtf1 So we're okay there, all right?}
{\rtf1 What about F. Raynor,\par the other user account?}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to change\par this and I'm going to see}
{\rtf1 what did F. Raynor do on DHSP01.}
{\rtf1 And we see these event ID threes.}
{\rtf1 These are network Sysmon events.}
{\rtf1 You can see network connections.}
{\rtf1 So in here we see PowerShell's\par making a network connection.}
{\rtf1 We've got another two\par more network connections,}
{\rtf1 still PowerShell.}
{\rtf1 It's PowerShell from IT01 and DHSP01.}
{\rtf1 Keep going, and you see another one,}
{\rtf1 still PowerShell, same thing.}
{\rtf1 We've got a actual PowerShell log here,}
{\rtf1 and we see enter PS session.}
{\rtf1 So if you're not familiar what that is,}
{\rtf1 that means a manual,\par interactive PowerShell terminal}
{\rtf1 remotely to this box,\par so from IT01 to DHSP01,}
{\rtf1 F. Raynor's account was remotely connected}
{\rtf1 and had access to a PowerShell\par terminal, manual access,}
{\rtf1 not a script, manual access.}
{\rtf1 And if you were to look at the other boxes}
{\rtf1 that were successful logons for F. Raynor,}
{\rtf1 it's PowerShell sessions.}
{\rtf1 So the question is what\par did he do on these boxes.}
{\rtf1 And if you looked into it further,}
{\rtf1 he basically connected\par and then disconnected.}
{\rtf1 4103, still PowerShell events.}
{\rtf1 This one is just a\par different PowerShell log,}
{\rtf1 and all's we see is the NRPS\par session and then nothing else.}
{\rtf1 So we don't know what's going on.}
{\rtf1 If it was a sysadmin function you}
{\rtf1 would think they would do something.}
{\rtf1 But all's this account was used was}
{\rtf1 to create a session and then disconnect.}
{\rtf1 So that's a little bit odd.}
{\rtf1 If you copy this command in,\par this is searching for F. Raynor}
{\rtf1 and things related to\par that NRPS session command.}
{\rtf1 And it maps directly to\par all the different boxes}
{\rtf1 that he had successful logons to.}
{\rtf1 So you can see all the different\par ones if you expand them.}
{\rtf1 We were on DHSP01.}
{\rtf1 Here's FS01.}
{\rtf1 So it's how we could confirm that that's}
{\rtf1 where these successful logons are for.}
{\rtf1 So that's unusual.}
{\rtf1 We probably would want to investigate,}
{\rtf1 see what's going on there, especially}
{\rtf1 when IT01 was the box\par that had pass-the-hash}
{\rtf1 and was doing the brute-force logons.}
{\rtf1 So that's really weird behavior.}
{\rtf1 Possibly F. Raynor was brute-forced,}
{\rtf1 and that's what's being used.}
{\rtf1 The last question we had with this lab}
{\rtf1 was dealing with the vulnerability scanner}
{\rtf1 being used improperly,\par so I'm going to look}
{\rtf1 for logons that are related to}
{\rtf1 the vulnerability scanner account.}
{\rtf1 This was provided at the scenario}
{\rtf1 at the beginning of the lab.}
{\rtf1 So I'll search for that,\par and we're going to see,}
{\rtf1 once this refreshes, the\par visualizations will map}
{\rtf1 to these logon events.}
{\rtf1 So we go down, and we're going to see...}
{\rtf1 We see DC02.}
{\rtf1 We see HR01.}
{\rtf1 What we're really dealing with though,}
{\rtf1 is we're trying to look at logon events}
{\rtf1 where the vulnerability scanner account's}
{\rtf1 being used improperly.}
{\rtf1 Logon type 10 is an RDP logon,}
{\rtf1 so we're seeing an RDP logon.}
{\rtf1 Expand this.}
{\rtf1 We're seeing it from the...}
{\rtf1 We have the user account, SVC vuln scan.}
{\rtf1 It is sourcing from 3.50 with\par a workstation name of DC02.}
{\rtf1 And it's logging in to\par the domain controller}
{\rtf1 cause it's authenticating\par against itself in this case.}
{\rtf1 So the vulnerability scanner account}
{\rtf1 is logging in with RDP\par to the domain controller.}
{\rtf1 That is an abnormal use for this.}
{\rtf1 You would not expect to see}
{\rtf1 the vulnerability scanner used that way.}
{\rtf1 Instead, you would expect to see it}
{\rtf1 sourcing from the vulnerability scanner.}
{\rtf1 And it probably would have\par been for SMB, not RDP.}
{\rtf1 So you'd see maybe a logon\par type of three, not 10.}
{\rtf1 So in this case the vulnerability\par scanner is jumping around.}
{\rtf1 We see it sourced from 3.50.}
{\rtf1 3.50 is HR01, so HR01 is logging in}
{\rtf1 from the vulnerability scanner}
{\rtf1 with the vulnerability scanner account,}
{\rtf1 to the domain controller.}
{\rtf1 You would expect to see that from}
{\rtf1 the vulnerability scanner itself.}
{\rtf1 Let's expand this, too.}
{\rtf1 Just take a look at this.}
{\rtf1 So here we go.}
{\rtf1 It's targeting DC02 using\par the vulnerability scanner.}
{\rtf1 The account being used\par initially was D. Brockaw.}
{\rtf1 So again we see a different\par user being involved here.}
{\rtf1 This whole scenario,\par there's basically a system}
{\rtf1 that's compromised, and the adversary}
{\rtf1 is jumping around, stealing credentials,}
{\rtf1 and using them in different ways,}
{\rtf1 pass-the-hash, brute-force\par logon, token smuggling,}
{\rtf1 all these different methods,\par to pivot around laterally}
{\rtf1 and get access they need.}
{\rtf1 So logon monitoring is something}
{\rtf1 you absolutely need to be doing.}
{\rtf1 You need to make sure you know}
{\rtf1 what your service accounts versus}
{\rtf1 your computer accounts,\par versus your user accounts.}
{\rtf1 And a kind of an extra\par thing you want to do}
{\rtf1 is you want to tag or identify}
{\rtf1 your sensitive user accounts so you can}
{\rtf1 hone in and see what's\par going on with those.}
{\rtf1 So logon monitoring is one\par of the most important things}
{\rtf1 you can do because adversaries,\par pen testers, malware,}
{\rtf1 they'd rather hide and mask themselves}
{\rtf1 as your accounts than\par constantly run exploits.}
{\rtf1 And quite frankly it just works.}
{\rtf1 So you have to be\par monitoring, and hopefully}
{\rtf1 this gives you a good idea\par of what you can monitor}
{\rtf1 and kind of how you\par could investigate these.}
